Award.AwardTitle: Surface Modification and Bioconjugation of Gold Nanorods
Award.AbstractNarration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 0906838 PI: Hamad-Schifferli, Kimberly ORG: MIT

Title: Surface Modification and Bioconjugation of Gold Nanorods

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Gold nanorods (NRs) possess unique physical properties, which have made them attractive for numerous biological applications such as drug delivery, photothermal therapy, sensing of biological binding events, and ultrasonic imaging contrast agents. The biggest barrier to widespread use of NRs in biological applications is their surface coating ligand. Synthesis of NRs requires the ligand cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), which is amphiphilic and forms a bilayer on the NR surface. Because CTAB binds weakly to the NR, it is fluxional, and therefore there must be excess free CTAB for the NRs to remain soluble in water. The CTAB coating not only complicates NR use in triggered release for drug delivery, but also prevents interfacing to biology. While surface chemistry of spherical nanoparticles (NPs) can be routinely modified, and NP conjugation to DNA and proteins and other biological molecules is straightforward, analogous success with Au NRs has not yet been achieved. Thus, there is a need for a way to customize the surface chemistry of NRs. A method that completely replaces CTAB with a variety of molecules is desirable. Single phase methods cannot remove CTAB completely, so the PI proposes to explore two-phase ligand extraction to modify Au NRs surfaces. She will test a range of molecules that can be put on the surface in order to expand the versatility of the surface chemistry of the NRs. The ligand exchanged NRs will be characterized by FTIR, optical absorption, TEM, electrophoretic mobility, and dynamic light scattering. Stability of the ligand-exchanged NRs will be assayed in water and buffers. After ligand exchange the NRs will be functionalized with thiolated DNA oligonucleotides of varying lengths (15-50mers). The DNA function will be probed by quantifying its ability to hybridize to a complement and also by measuring the biophysical properties of the NR-DNA conjugates such as zeta potential and hydrodynamic radius. The stability of the NR-DNA conjugates will be assayed, and the conditions and surface chemistry that maximize DNA loading and function will be determined.

BROADER IMPACTS: Potential applications of surface-modified NRs include use as drug delivery or photothermal devices triggered by highly penetrating infrared radiation in a wavelength range where water and tissue are generally transparent. Many imaging applications can also be envisaged for NRs targeted for specific tissues. The PI describes in detail a planned workshop designed to inform female (and male) students about successful strategies for negotiating a successful academic or scientific career while raising a family.

Gold nanorods possess unique physical properties, which have made them attractive for numerous biological applications such as photothermal therapy, sensing of biological binding events, and ultrasonic imaging contrast agents. Because femtosecond laser pulses can locally heat nanorods, they have been use for triggered release of drugs and DNA and burning tumors. Due to their shape, nanorods absorb strongly in the infrared. Since this absorption coincides with the wavelength range where water and tissue are transparent, there is the potential to implement them in through-tissue applications. However, the biggest barrier to widespread use of nanorods in biological applications is their surface coating chemistry. nanorods are synthesized with the molecule cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), which is amphiphilic and forms a bilayer on the nanorod surface. Because CTAB binds weakly to the nanorod, it is fluxional, and therefore there must be excess free CTAB for the nanorods to remain soluble in water. Unfortunately, nanorods coated with CTAB aggregate in buffers and biological fluids, preventing decoration of nanorods with DNA and proteins. Furthermore, free CTAB is toxic. In addition, the physical properties of nanorods that are exploited in triggered drug delivery and photothermal therapy are the thermal dissipation of nanorods and their ability to release molecules, and both of these properties are strongly influenced by the concentration of CTAB both on and off the nanorod surface. Thus, the CTAB coating not only complicates nanorod use in triggered release for drug delivery, but also prevents interfacing to biology.

We came up with a simple, accessible way to modify the surface chemistry of gold nanorods with molecules that make the nanorods biocompatible and thus more amenable for biological applications. This allowed us to explore how the surface coating ligand affects their physical, chemical, and biological behavior. For this purpose we developed techniques and tools for quantifying the physical properties of the nanorods with these different ligands. Using these tools we examined the impact of the nanorods on cell behavior to answer the question regarding how surface chemistry affects the response of cells when they are exposed to nanorods. Interestingly, we found that the surface chemistry can make significant differences on the biological consequences of the nanorods, which indicates that choosing the right molecule to coat nanorods and nanoparticles in general is critical.

As part of the broader impact of the proposed project, the PI tried to address issues of gender imbalance in STEM careers. The problem of the “leaky pipeline” is well-known but we are still trying to get a good understanding of the factors that cause it. In particular, the issue of tenure occurring during child-bearing years is one that prevents so many women from pursuing careers in academics. Many top-notch graduate students shy away from academia because they want to raise families. This is not surprising given the dismaying statistics on the rates of tenure for women who have children within 5 years of their Ph.D. degree, as shown in the “Do Babies Matter?” report from U.C. Berkeley. This is a major question on the mind of female Ph.D. students and postdocs, one that factors heavily in their decision to pursue an academic job. Some mechanisms exist to help, such as stopping the tenure clock for those who bear a child during the tenure process. However, this cannot simply combat the fact that the number of women faculty who have children during their tenure track are so few.
